componenttextpreview: Inconsequential for Newfield, a bigger issue for industry and a real big issue for the local community.
componenttext: Inconsequential for Newfield, a bigger issue for industry and a real big issue for the local community.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: We will now take our next question from Leo Mariani from NatAlliance Securities.
componenttext: We will now take our next question from Leo Mariani from NatAlliance Securities.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Obviously, I guess at this point in the year, you folks have increased production guidance here twice in 2018. I know there's a little bit more CapEx associated with it. But just want to get a sense of whether or not the well performance in 2018 may be tr
componenttext: Obviously, I guess at this point in the year, you folks have increased production guidance here twice in 2018. I know there's a little bit more CapEx associated with it. But just want to get a sense of whether or not the well performance in 2018 may be tracking a little bit better than expected? And is that one of the key drivers here behind the raises?

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that there are a number of factors. Obviously, if we weren't delivering results, strong results consistent with the plan, then we wouldn't have posted the strong first half. So I think the first thing is that all of the assumptions that
componenttext: Well, I would say that there are a number of factors. Obviously, if we weren't delivering results, strong results consistent with the plan, then we wouldn't have posted the strong first half. So I think the first thing is that all of the assumptions that our team built in are intact with regard to performance through the first half of the year. Clearly, we talked about the gas and NGL component. I think that it's important for people to realize that part of the increase in NGLs is that it's economically advantageous to process, and that's something that fits in the realm of us talking about making economic decisions. So that decision in and of itself drives some of those volumes, but it's also a good outcome in terms of when we think about the economics and cash flow kind of across the portfolio. I've got no reason at this point to articulate any adjustments to the work product that has been generated and went into the plan. I think most important, we referenced in the call, is we've got 5 or 6 multi-well DSUs that are inset into the central portion of our footprint, distributed along strike, that really -- those -- the results of those multi-well DSUs will underpin our 3-year plan. So that second half of the year, watching those results roll off, is going to be a pretty critical factor. But net-net, I'm very, very pleased with what our team has delivered in the first half of the year, all fronts.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess just a question here on hedging. Obviously, you guys are very well hedged in 2018 and prices have done very well on the oil side. And just trying to get a sense of how you guys think about approaching hedging as you work
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess just a question here on hedging. Obviously, you guys are very well hedged in 2018 and prices have done very well on the oil side. And just trying to get a sense of how you guys think about approaching hedging as you work your way into 2019. I mean, at this point, you kind of hit free cash flow positive, do you tell yourself that maybe we don't need to be as hedged, particularly in light of the fact that the curve is still pretty backwardated. Just trying to get a sense that there might be any subtle shifts in hedging philosophy as you work your way into next year.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: So, I'll take the first part of that, and then I'll flip it to Larry since we're both an active participant in terms of our hedge committee. I think that when you turn backwards, if you go back to 2017, you remember how that played out, average oil price
componenttext: So, I'll take the first part of that, and then I'll flip it to Larry since we're both an active participant in terms of our hedge committee. I think that when you turn backwards, if you go back to 2017, you remember how that played out, average oil price was $51. We and others in the industry were striving to get to free cash flow generation. We saw buoyancy in the price, but it wasn't obvious that things were going to play out the way that they have. So we hedged strongly to protect our -- against the downside but mostly to ensure our ability to execute and get to free cash flow positive conditions in 2018. So that's how you think about the hedge book that we've got, that we're living with in 2018. In general, we've held [ back ] for several months and haven't added to the 2019 position and we're wide open in 2020. I think those are important points because it tells you we're fully exposed to the market in 2020, and 2/3 exposed to the market right now for 2019. So that's just kind of how to think about it in the big picture, and I'll let Larry give you the color on the other points that you were asking about.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you, Lee. Coming out of the price collapse and coming out of it with cash on our balance sheet, kind of leads us to not having to hedge quite as much, and certainly kind of mimic the forward curve as you see that backwardation, as Lee points ou
componenttext: Yes. Thank you, Lee. Coming out of the price collapse and coming out of it with cash on our balance sheet, kind of leads us to not having to hedge quite as much, and certainly kind of mimic the forward curve as you see that backwardation, as Lee points out. We've been taking advantage of going relatively short on our hedges. That's proved to be the right move for us. And you'll probably see that going forward as long as the curve stays backwardated and affords us the opportunity to wait and capture maybe another $5 or $6 per barrel.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: We will take our next question from Biju Perincheril from Susquehanna.
componenttext: We will take our next question from Biju Perincheril from Susquehanna.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Lee, going back to the sort of the new techniques for completing wells and to address the parent-child, can you talk about if there is any impact to low cost, is that already included in your -- through your average of, I think, $7.6 million to $8.7 milli
componenttext: Lee, going back to the sort of the new techniques for completing wells and to address the parent-child, can you talk about if there is any impact to low cost, is that already included in your -- through your average of, I think, $7.6 million to $8.7 million completed well cost?

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the way to think about is there's obviously incremental costs. Anytime we're experimenting, it's incremental cost. The costs are relatively modest when you think about spreading them across the DSU, where you've got 6, 8, 10, 12 wells that yo
componenttext: Yes, I think the way to think about is there's obviously incremental costs. Anytime we're experimenting, it's incremental cost. The costs are relatively modest when you think about spreading them across the DSU, where you've got 6, 8, 10, 12 wells that you're talking about drilling. The extra cost, when you see it, are probably going to be mostly in the areas of some incremental water handling and LOE-type expenses. Obviously, there's cost for getting the equipment doing the work, but it's relatively minor when you look at it across the DSU. I would say that probably you're talking about something that's, on a gross basis, $1 million, $1.5 million, somewhere in that zip code is the kind of cost, so pretty modest. And if you're able to mitigate depletion effects relative to the parent, it's well offset with the production performance of DSU. That's the way we think about it in terms of what we're trying to do. Gary, do you have any other color you want to offer on that?

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. At the end of the day, since we're oftentimes working in one of the original wells, it's going to materialize as a major expense and it's not going to show up as CapEx.
componenttext: Yes. At the end of the day, since we're oftentimes working in one of the original wells, it's going to materialize as a major expense and it's not going to show up as CapEx.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Got it. And when I think about sort of the impact to that #2 well, I would think it'll also depend on the completion design of the parent well, and I mean not just the fluid loading or proppant loading, but also the variables that control the frac length.
componenttext: Got it. And when I think about sort of the impact to that #2 well, I would think it'll also depend on the completion design of the parent well, and I mean not just the fluid loading or proppant loading, but also the variables that control the frac length. And can you talk about the evolution of the completion design on the parent wells, when did that change?

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I -- I don't know if you were on, on the call earlier, but I referenced that in an earlier question. I think what's important to note, if you were -- knowing everything that you and we in the industry know today, if you had a development and you c
componenttext: Yes, so I -- I don't know if you were on, on the call earlier, but I referenced that in an earlier question. I think what's important to note, if you were -- knowing everything that you and we in the industry know today, if you had a development and you could fast-forward 6, 7 years into the future on some new development with all the learnings that you've got, you would go back to time 0 and say what I really want when I go through an HBP, the acreage are low-intensity completions because I don't want to create problems for myself in development. Well, what you have today is we stayed for 3 years with low-intensity completions to learn about the reservoir targets that we were setting up to develop. If you go back in that time period, the first 3 years or so in the play when we were talking about it, we held completion constant. And I've made reference, 950 by 950, so 950 gallons, 950 pounds proppant per foot. That's half the intensity of the completions that we pumped on average in 2017 as an example. So our team already took the step on the front end of planning for development with very low-intensity parent. There was a period, and there has been in any one of these plays, because some of you listening on the call out there love big wells. I call it the nuclear arms race, my well's bigger than yours. And we've certainly drilled some big wells as well just to prove that, yes, our acreage is capable of showing those big wells. The truth is, we kept that to a minimum. We kept it to a minimum for a reason because we knew we were going to have to come back and develop. The bigger the parent well, the more intensive the completion, the larger the stimulated rock volume, the larger the depletion effects that you have to deal with when you come back in development. So just think through that as you think about the next iteration and the next play. But as far as where we sit, I like how our team attacked the development. It's been very logical, it's been methodical. It's been well thought out. And today, we're mitigating those effects and having success. But I think it's all tied together with 6 or 7 years of planning to get to this stage. I hope that's clear, but that's the best answer I can give you. I'm glad that [indiscernible]...

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: We will now take our next question from Subash Chandra from Guggenheim.
componenttext: We will now take our next question from Subash Chandra from Guggenheim.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Lee, a question on SCOOP, sort of look at the trajectory there. It looks like you've got some activity level this year, next year, then peaking. Is that -- do you consider that base production? Or is there a plan maybe at a future date to come back to the
componenttext: Lee, a question on SCOOP, sort of look at the trajectory there. It looks like you've got some activity level this year, next year, then peaking. Is that -- do you consider that base production? Or is there a plan maybe at a future date to come back to the SCOOP?

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, there's upside in SCOOP and some of the risings that we've referenced, the Sycamore, the Caney intervals, would be 2 that I would reference. There's also exposure down there, a portion of the acreage in the Springer, some of which is being a
componenttext: Well, I mean, there's upside in SCOOP and some of the risings that we've referenced, the Sycamore, the Caney intervals, would be 2 that I would reference. There's also exposure down there, a portion of the acreage in the Springer, some of which is being actively drilled by industry today. Ultimately, we also have the possibility of going back at the right place and time to infill the original development which we look at. And the Woodford, we look at today as having been underdeveloped but a big production base. So he's an example of the things people will deal with. You've got a big production base. It's cash flow. You're not going to go back and put that at risk. So -- and in fact, by drilling through these acreage positions and developing them, you put some of the stages of development spread out over time. So there's lots of things we can go back to there. Ultimately, we'll make the decision on investing there on the basis of how it competes within the portfolio. There's a -- it's all HBP, so I've already talked about multiple layers. We're actively finishing up the HBP at North SCOOP as we speak. So most of the production I referenced is down in what we would call South SCOOP. It's good dirt to hold, so we've secured the option for the future. And presently on all sides, there's tons of private activity. So just sitting back and watching, we're building a database of how those things are going to perform. So right now, we're focused on pushing the development STACK and we're still drilling wells down at SCOOP. But it'll have another phase --another phase of -- probably sometime actively towards the back end of the plan or after the 3-year plan, will be my guess.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay. And any update in that McClain County area, the EOG-type area?
componenttext: Okay. And any update in that McClain County area, the EOG-type area?

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll just say what I've said before, it's nice having EOG as a partner. I'm glad that they have so many premium wells abutting our locations. I'm glad we got there several years before, they'd own it all. So that's probably all I can say. We've got
componenttext: Well, I'll just say what I've said before, it's nice having EOG as a partner. I'm glad that they have so many premium wells abutting our locations. I'm glad we got there several years before, they'd own it all. So that's probably all I can say. We've got good well results there, it's part of our development inventory and Gary and the team will further that in over time.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: We will now take our next question from Ron Mills from Johnson Rice.
componenttext: We will now take our next question from Ron Mills from Johnson Rice.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: A quick question, the 2018 production profile and the multi-pad completions has been well talked about. But when we look at 2019 and where the [ rigs ] are going to be located on, on the multi-pad completions, can you give us some color as to where that a
componenttext: A quick question, the 2018 production profile and the multi-pad completions has been well talked about. But when we look at 2019 and where the [ rigs ] are going to be located on, on the multi-pad completions, can you give us some color as to where that activity is located within your phase window? Is it more in the black oil window? And when does that concept of road drilling really start to get completed?

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: First of all, 2019 forward plans for STACK is going to be largely road drilling or you want to call it bounded cube drilling, there's lots of different phrases people are using it for, but -- using these days, but it's all the same concept. In general, we
componenttext: First of all, 2019 forward plans for STACK is going to be largely road drilling or you want to call it bounded cube drilling, there's lots of different phrases people are using it for, but -- using these days, but it's all the same concept. In general, we'll attack that moving from west to east. I referenced the multi-well -- the 5 multi-well DSUs that we've drilled up on the leading edge of our development footprint in the 3-year plan. We'll have that production information starting to come back to us in the back half of this year. All of that will be incorporated to further refine our forecast '19 forward. Fourth quarter is probably when you'll really see, if you look closely at the CapEx in the fourth quarter, part of the reason it's down is that we're going -- we're shifting into drilling the first road drilling. So those completions actually hit early in 2019. We also -- because you're going across the acreage in an orderly fashion, we're going to drill through areas that have different working interests. So it just so happens where we're starting, the working interest on average is down some 20 points over what we've done year-to-date. But it's the right thing to do. It's the right way to think about development and we're going to transition there starting late this year.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then on the Northwest STACK, it seems, at least from the diagram on your presentation, that the area where the Meramec becomes present again in Dewey County is relatively small. Do you feel like you've locked up a lot of the acreage aroun
componenttext: Okay, great. And then on the Northwest STACK, it seems, at least from the diagram on your presentation, that the area where the Meramec becomes present again in Dewey County is relatively small. Do you feel like you've locked up a lot of the acreage around where that Meramec reappears?

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. We didn't buy the acreage by accident. I think our geological team did some good work there identifying that geologic horizon is existing in that place. That's why we captured the acreage. You're right. It's, in general, a smaller overall area extent
componenttext: Yes. We didn't buy the acreage by accident. I think our geological team did some good work there identifying that geologic horizon is existing in that place. That's why we captured the acreage. You're right. It's, in general, a smaller overall area extent and we like the acreage we own.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: We now have time for one more question. Richard Tullis from Capital One Securities.
componenttext: We now have time for one more question. Richard Tullis from Capital One Securities.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Lee, I know you have the 3-year plan outlook for oil growth, I think it's 17% to 21% CAGR. Given current view on the second half of this year, what do you expect 2019 domestic oil production growth range could look like, say, if CapEx was similar next yea
componenttext: Lee, I know you have the 3-year plan outlook for oil growth, I think it's 17% to 21% CAGR. Given current view on the second half of this year, what do you expect 2019 domestic oil production growth range could look like, say, if CapEx was similar next year?

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I'll just reference the 3-year plan. We've put a lot of work into it. We've told everybody at -- in the beginning of this year that it was a plan we can execute against. I think we're halfway through the first year of that, and I think the te
componenttext: Yes, I think I'll just reference the 3-year plan. We've put a lot of work into it. We've told everybody at -- in the beginning of this year that it was a plan we can execute against. I think we're halfway through the first year of that, and I think the team 's executing very strongly. You have to concede that there've been a lot of changes in terms of -- we talked about politics and markets and tariffs and all kinds of things that you've got to incorporate into your decision-making. I think we'll stay on the schedule that we've developed over the last several years that will give you our best look at '19 forward, if there any adjustments early in '19, let's call it, February of '19. That's our plan.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: That's fair enough. And just lastly, Lee, when you look at Oklahoma increasing production taxes last year and then the issue that came up in Kingfisher County on the water transportation handling, how do you view the landscape there now regulatory, tax-wi
componenttext: That's fair enough. And just lastly, Lee, when you look at Oklahoma increasing production taxes last year and then the issue that came up in Kingfisher County on the water transportation handling, how do you view the landscape there now regulatory, tax-wise? And then does it cause you to perhaps look to expand activity outside the stage or even perhaps look at entering a new area?

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that you can look at the results we're posting, that despite all of the, what we call, headwinds, we're still generating strong returns, strong growth, good strong cash flow from our assets. So I'd be remiss not to point that out. But cl
componenttext: Well, I would say that you can look at the results we're posting, that despite all of the, what we call, headwinds, we're still generating strong returns, strong growth, good strong cash flow from our assets. So I'd be remiss not to point that out. But clearly, the GPT is the most significant headwind that we've been handed. The truth of the matter is there've been a couple of tax iterations in Oklahoma over the last couple of years. And the most recent adjustment, which was this year, is substantial. And I think that the focus from our standpoint as a team -- management team and board, is we're going to work every day to claw back what that GPT increase takes away, and we'll keep all options on the table in terms of attacking that issue. Ultimately, I'm confident, we're confident, that Oklahoma officials understand the importance of our industry in the state and our company's investment in that state. So we're counting on the leadership there to get things right and maintain Oklahoma's position as a competitive place to do business. So at this stage, we're monitoring the situation. We're on the front lines. We're going to work hard to make up for the negative effects of the tax changes on the road ahead. Well, I want to thank everybody -- I think we're finished now, thank everybody for dialing in this morning. Appreciate your investment and interest in the company. We'll look forward to updating you again as we progress through this year. And good luck to everyone. Thank you.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you. That will conclude today's conference call. Thank you for your participation. Ladies and gentlemen, you may now disconnect.
componenttext: Thank you. That will conclude today's conference call. Thank you for your participation. Ladies and gentlemen, you may now disconnect.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. Please note that today's call is being recorded, and will be available on our website along with our earnings release, the accompanying financial tables and non-GAAP reconciliations. We will referen
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. Please note that today's call is being recorded, and will be available on our website along with our earnings release, the accompanying financial tables and non-GAAP reconciliations. We will reference certain non-GAAP measures so please see the reconciliations in our earnings release. 
Today's discussion contains forward-looking estimates and assumptions that are based on our current views and reasonable expectations. In summary, statements in yesterday's news release and in our call this morning regarding our expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements and intended to be covered by the safe harbor provisions under the federal securities laws. 
There are many factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations, including those that we've described in the earnings release, our 10-K, our 10-Q, our prior outlook release and other filings with the SEC. Please refer to these legends in our earnings release for additional information. 
With that, I'll turn it over to my boss, Lee Boothby

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our conference call today. This is a big day for our company and our shareholders. Earlier this morning, we announced that we've entered into a definitive merger agreement with Encana Corporation i
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our conference call today. This is a big day for our company and our shareholders. Earlier this morning, we announced that we've entered into a definitive merger agreement with Encana Corporation in an all stock transaction. We're looking forward to providing you with highlights from this quarter as well as key highlights from this transaction. We're planning to keep this call very brief as our employees will be gathering down the street to hear from Doug Suttles and myself immediately after today's call. 
This transaction will create a leading North American multi-basin company and we're confident that it's in the best interest of our owners. When combined, our companies will have the key attributes that should be differentiated in today's energy sector. 
In short, we're taking 2 great companies and creating an even better one. We will have scale. Combined, we will have core of the core acreage and some of the best liquids rich basins across North America and our net daily production will exceed 575,000 BOE per day, of which more than half will be liquids. 
The union will create one of the largest onshore liquids companies in North America. 
Importantly, the combination of the 2 companies and the quality of the assets will generate long term growth while generating excess cash that can be returned to shareholders through dividends and buybacks as you may have seen with Encana's announcement today on their additional shareholder-friendly initiatives. 
Over the last few months, we've clearly heard from our largest investors and we know that the return of cash to owners is a mandate on the road ahead. This unique combination will offer the ongoing development of our assets to create the most value for shareholders. 
Let's move on to the third quarter financial results. Newfield posted a very solid third quarter. Our consolidated net production in the third quarter was more than 202,000 BOE per day. Our domestic production in the quarter came in about 9,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day or 5% above the midpoint of our guidance, up more than 25% year-over-year. 
Our third quarter net production in the SCOOP and the STACK was nearly 144,000 BOE per day, up more than 35% year-over-year. 
Third quarter net liquids in the basin was in line with guidance, averaging approximately 87,000 barrels per day. Oil production from Anadarko Basin grew 17% year-over-year to 43,200 barrels of oil per day, in line with guidance. 
Our consolidated third quarter revenues were $711 million. Net cash provided by operating activities was $349 million and discretionary cash flow from operations was $373 million. 
With near line and our capital investments and cash flows, we have maintained a strong cash balance and ended the quarter with $264 million of cash on hand.  Our third quarter earnings and cash flow per share came in above Street's estimates. 
Adjusting for the items noted in our news release, our net income for the quarter would have been $204 million or $1.01 per share. Please see the explanation and reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures at the end of our third quarter release. 
We continue to see great results in the SCOOP and the STACK and we are, today, increasing our full year Anadarko Basin net production guidance to 130,000 to 135,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day and our full year total domestic net production guidance is being raised to 185,000 to 190,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. 
Full year capital investments are expected to be approximately $1.4 billion ex-capitalized internal cost. This compares to prior guidance of $1.35 billion. The additional investment in the fourth quarter are primarily related to accelerated completions in the Anadarko Basin and the continuation of our operated rig in Uinta Basin through the end of the year. 
Now I'd like to take a moment to share some brief highlights from each of our active growing programs. We continue to see solid well results in STACK and we have rapidly migrated to cube development, commencing road drilling operations across multiple drilling units. This effort will allow the team to optimize completions, test simultaneous cube development at the Meramec, Osage and Woodford formations and reduce downtime associated with the outside operating activities. 
Our Williston team has continued to be a premier operator in the basin and we expect to generate more than $140 million of excess cash in the Williston in 2018. 
In the Uinta, the company has grown production 16% year-over-year with a single rig program and is now producing approximately 20,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day net to the company. 
Before closing out today's call, let me, again, reiterate our enthusiasm for today's announced transaction. Upon closing, this unique combination creates a dominant, multi-basin company with core of the core positions in 3 of the top North American liquids plays. This union will come with nearly 600,000 barrels of equivalent net daily production and a deep inventory of projects for future development. 
Perhaps most importantly, it provides what we think investors are demanding today, a unique balance of profitable growth and a return of cash to the shareholder. 
Thanks for your time this morning. We look forward to seeing you on the road ahead. Good day.

Upon closing, this unique combination creates a dominant, multi-basin company with core-of-the-core positions in 3 of the top North American liquids plays. This union will come with nearly 600,000 barrels of equivalent net daily production and a deep inventory of projects for future development. Perhaps, most importantly, it provides what we think investors are demanding today, a unique balance of profitable growth and a return of cash to the shareholder. 
Thanks for your time this morning. We look forward to seeing you on the road ahead. Good day.

Please note that today's call is being recorded and will be available on our website, along with our earnings release, the accompanying financial tables and non-GAAP reconciliations. We will reference certain non-GAAP measures so please see the reconciliations in our earnings release. 
Today's discussion contains forward-looking estimates and assumptions that are based on our current views and reasonable expectations. In summary, statements in yesterday's news release and on our call this morning regarding our expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements and intended to be covered by the safe harbor provisions under federal securities laws.

Please refer to these legends in our earnings release for additional information. 
With that, I'll turn it over to my boss, Lee Boothby.

headline: Newfield Exploration Company, Q3 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our conference call today. This is a big day for our company and our shareholders. Early this morning, we announced that we've entered into a definitive merger agreement with Encana Corporation in
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our conference call today. This is a big day for our company and our shareholders. Early this morning, we announced that we've entered into a definitive merger agreement with Encana Corporation in an all-stock transaction. We're looking forward to providing you with highlights from this quarter as well as key highlights from this transaction. We're planning to keep this call very brief as our employees will be gathering down the street to hear from Doug Suttles and myself immediately after today's call. 
This transaction will create a leading North American multi-basin company, and we are confident that it's in the best interest of our owners. When combined, our companies will have the key attributes that should be differentiated in today's energy sector. In short, we're taking 2 great companies and creating an even better one. We will have scale, combined. We will have core-of-the-core acreage and some of the best liquids-rich basins across North America, and our net daily production will exceed 575,000 BOE per day, of which more than half will be liquids. The union will create one of the largest onshore liquids companies in North America. 
Importantly, the combination of the 2 companies and the quality of the assets will generate long-term growth while generating excess cash that can be returned to shareholders through dividends and buybacks, as you may have seen with Encana's announcement today on their additional shareholder-friendly initiatives. 
Over the last few months, we have clearly heard from our largest investors and we know that a return of cash to owners is a mandate on the road ahead. This unique combination will allow for the ongoing development of our assets to create the most value for shareholders. 
Let's move on to the third quarter financial results. Newfield posted a very solid third quarter. Our consolidated net production in the third quarter was more than 202,000 BOE per day. Our domestic production in the quarter came in about 9,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day or 5% above the midpoint of our guidance, up more than 25% year-over-year. 
Our third quarter net production in the SCOOP and the STACK was nearly 144,000 BOE per day, up more than 35% year-over-year. 
Third quarter net liquids in the basin was in line with guidance, averaging approximately 87,000 barrels per day. Oil production from the Anadarko Basin grew 17% year-over-year to 43,200 barrels of oil per day, in line with guidance. Our consolidated third quarter revenues were $711 million. Net cash provided by operating activities was $349 million and discretionary cash flow from operations was $373 million. 
With near alignment in our capital investments and cash flows, we have maintained a strong cash balance and ended the quarter with $264 million of cash on hand.  Our third quarter earnings and cash flow per share came in above Street estimates. 
Adjusting for the items noted in our news release, our net income for the quarter would have been $204 million or $1.01 per share. Please see the explanation and reconciliation of the non-GAAP financial measures at the end of our third quarter release. 
We continue to see great results in the SCOOP and the STACK, and we are, today, increasing our full year Anadarko Basin net production guidance to 130,000 to 135,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, and our full year total domestic net production guidance is being raised to 185,000 to 190,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. 
Full year capital investments are expected to be approximately $1.4 billion ex-capitalized internal cost. This compares to prior guidance of $1.35 billion. The additional investments in the fourth quarter are primarily related to accelerated completions in the Anadarko Basin and the continuation of our operated rig in Uinta Basin through the end of the year. 
Now I'd like to take a moment to share some brief highlights from each of our active growing programs. We continue to see solid well results in STACK, and we have rapidly migrated to cube development, commencing road-drilling operations across multiple drilling units. This effort will allow the team to optimize completions, test simultaneous cube development at the Meramec, Osage and Woodford formations and reduce downtime associated with the outside-operated activities. 
Our Williston team has continued to be a premier operator in the basin and we expect to generate more than $140 million of excess cash in Williston in 2018. 
In the Uinta, the company has grown production 16% year-over-year with the single rig program and is now producing approximately 20,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, net to the company. 
Before closing out today's call, let me, again, reiterate our enthusiasm for today's announced transaction. Upon closing, this unique combination creates a dominant, multi-basin company with core-of-the-core positions in 3 of the top North American liquids plays. This union will come with nearly 600,000 barrels of equivalent net daily production and a deep inventory of projects for future development. Perhaps, most importantly, it provides what we think investors are demanding today, a unique balance of profitable growth and a return of cash to the shareholder. 
Thanks for your time this morning. We look forward to seeing you on the road ahead. Good day.
